Oh, good point @carpodaster! I tbh didn't even know about git mv 🙈 and also did not look into the details of the changeset...
However, the way I understand it, git mv is only a shortcut for moving a file and then git add the changes in one command. So I think the history of files should still be fine - it's just that Github cannot display the changes in another way apparently...

If you for instance look at an apparently new file, you'll still see the history - see this for example.

Do you know of anything I could do to make the changeset easier to read or pick up the changes in a different way? Would git mv do this?

body:
Oh, good point @carpodaster! I tbh didn't even know about `git mv` 🙈 and also did not look into the details of the changeset...
However, the way I understand it, `git mv` is only a shortcut for moving a file and then `git add` the changes in one command. So I think the history of files should still be fine - it's just that Github cannot display the changes in another way apparently...

If you for instance look at an apparently new file, you'll still see the history - [see this for example](https://github.com/rails-girls-summer-of-code/rgsoc-teams/blame/2ee67565a11d1acd4114673beb0bcbf212da9dad/app/controllers/mentors/applications_controller.rb).

Do you know of anything I could do to make the changeset easier to read or pick up the changes in a different way? Would `git mv` do this?
